Meet Ava: the Whatsapp Agent

Lesson 1: Course Overview

What happens when two ML Engineers with a love for sci-fi movies team up? ü§î

You get Ava, a Whatsapp agent that can engage with users in a realistic way, inspired by the great film Ex Machina. Ok, let‚Äôs be real, you won‚Äôt be building a fully sentient robot in this project, but you will enjoy some pretty interesting Whatsapp conversations. I can assure you that! üòÅ

Check the code here! üßë‚Äçüíª

This course is divided into six lessons:

üèóÔ∏è Lesson 1: Project overview

üï∏Ô∏è Lesson 2: Ava's brain is just a graph

üß† Lesson 3: Unlocking Ava's memories

üó£Ô∏è Lesson 4: Giving Ava a Voice

üëÄ Lesson 5: Ava learns to see

üì± Lesson 6: Ava installs Whatsapp

Today, we‚Äôll start with the first lesson - a general introduction to the project and its core components.

Project Overview

Ava is a "Whatsapp Agent‚Äù, meaning it will interact with you through this app. But it won‚Äôt just rely on ‚Äúregular‚Äù text messages, it will also listen to your voice notes (yes, even if you are one of those people üòí)and react to your pictures.

And that‚Äôs not all ‚Ä¶ Ava can also respond with its own voice notes and images of what it‚Äôs up to - yes, Ava has a life beyond talking to you, don‚Äôt be such a narcissist! üòÇ

At this point, you might be wondering:

What kind of system have we implemented to handle multimodal inputs / outputs coherently?

The short answer: Ava‚Äôs brain is just a graph ‚Ä¶ a LangGraph üï∏Ô∏è (sorry, I couldn‚Äôt resist).

üí† Ava‚Äôs Graph

Your brain is made up of neurons, right? Well, Ava‚Äôs brain is made up of LangGraph nodes and edges - one for the processing images, another for listening to your voice, another for fetching relevant memories, and so on.

At its core, Ava is simply a graph with a state. This state maintains all the key details of the conversation, including shared information (text, audio or images), current activities, and contextual information.

This is exactly what we‚Äôll explore in Lesson 2, where you‚Äôll learn how LangGraph can be used to build agentic design architectures, such as the router.

üí† Ava‚Äôs memory

An Agent without memory is like talking to the main character of ‚ÄúMemento‚Äù (and if you haven‚Äôt seen that film‚Ä¶ seriously, what are you doing with your life?).

Ava has two types of memory:

üî∑ Short term memory

The usual - it stores the sequence of messages to maintain conversation context. In our case, we save this sequence in SQLite (we are also storing a summary of the conversation, but that‚Äôs for future lessons üòâ).

üî∑ Long term memory

When you meet someone, you don‚Äôt remember everything they say; you retain only the key details, like their name, profession, or where they‚Äôre from, right?. That‚Äôs exactly what we wanted to replicate with Qdrant - extracting relevant information from the conversation and storing it as embeddings.

Don‚Äôt worry because we‚Äôll cover the memory modules in Lesson 3.

üí† Ava‚Äôs senses

Real Whatsapp conversations aren‚Äôt limited to just text. Think about it - do you remember the last cringe GIF your mom sent you last week? Or that neverending voice note from your high school friend? Exactly. We need both images and audio.

To make this possible, we‚Äôve selected the following tools.

üî∑ Text

Both Jes√∫s and I are Groq fans (if you chat with Ava, ask about its job, you might be surprised). That‚Äôs why we are using Groq models for all text generation. Specifically, we‚Äôve chosen llama-3.3-70b-versatile as our core LLM.

üî∑ Images

The image module handles two tasks: processing user images and generating new ones (take a look at the image below).

  • For image ‚Äúunderstanding‚Äù, we‚Äôre using Groq‚Äôs llama-3.2-90b-vision-preview.

  • For image generation, black-forest-labs/FLUX.1-schnell-Free using Together AI.

üî∑ Audio

The audio module needs to take care of TTS (Text-To-Speech) and STT (Speech-To-Text).

  • For TTS, we are using Elevenlabs voices.

  • For STT, whisper-large-v3-turbo from Groq.

We‚Äôll cover the audio module in Lesson 4 and the image module in Lesson 5!

And that‚Äôs all for today! As you can see, this is a very complete course, so we hope you‚Äôre excited to get started with it! Remember, Lesson 2 will be available next Wednesday, February 12th. Every lesson (including this one) comes with a complementary video on Jes√∫s Copados‚Äô YouTube channel.

We strongly recommend exploring both resources (written lessons and video lessons) to maximize your learning experience! üôÇ

üì± Happy Whatsapping! üì±
